snippet.textDisplay: In biology there is a prevailing theory of how populations propagate. Its usually expressed as something called a K-line. It give some broad avenues of what a population can do, how fast it can do it, and how that will affect the stability of that population going forward. The idea, in a nutshell, is that exponential growth of a population in a biome can only be sustained for so long. Resources become depleted. How quickly those resources replenish helps determine where the population falls on the k-line. If the relationship is stable, some of the population may die but the biome achieves some level of homeostatic equilibrium and the populations that rely on each other will rise and fall in, roughly, sine waves. The other broad choice is collapse of the population, which in this case would be rapidly infecting everyone, leaving the virus no new prey unless it rapidly mutates. The problem is that the k-line is about how populations of organisms interact, and in this case we are the prey being depleted. Both populations can be crashed by overconsumption, first of the prey itself and then everything else down the chain as panic spreads and holes appear in, presumably, once stable biomes.
snippet.textOriginal: In biology there is a prevailing theory of how populations propagate. Its usually expressed as something called a K-line. It give some broad avenues of what a population can do, how fast it can do it, and how that will affect the stability of that population going forward. The idea, in a nutshell, is that exponential growth of a population in a biome can only be sustained for so long. Resources become depleted. How quickly those resources replenish helps determine where the population falls on the k-line. If the relationship is stable, some of the population may die but the biome achieves some level of homeostatic equilibrium and the populations that rely on each other will rise and fall in, roughly, sine waves. The other broad choice is collapse of the population, which in this case would be rapidly infecting everyone, leaving the virus no new prey unless it rapidly mutates. The problem is that the k-line is about how populations of organisms interact, and in this case we are the prey being depleted. Both populations can be crashed by overconsumption, first of the prey itself and then everything else down the chain as panic spreads and holes appear in, presumably, once stable biomes.

snippet.textDisplay:
At 1:31 they flash the text "*Hertzsprung-Russell, anyone?".

If anyone is curious, Hertzsprung-Russell diagrams, or HRDs, originated from scatter plots comparing a star's luminosity to its temperature. These scatter plots all have a main sequence, which I suppose in context would be the countries that have not dropped from the logarithmic curve or countries that do not appear to have the disease under control yet. The video does not mention HRDs by name, I'm assuming because we're not talking about stars, but its the exact same concept.

These HRDs also do not plot against time to make it easier to see an overall effect (same as discussed in the video). This feature, in many cases such as with Covid-19, makes it MUCH easier to analyze data and predict future outcomes. If you want to simulate a time dimension, imagine the lines drawing themselves as countries' plotted curves are added to day by day (he explains how this is shown through animation).

That's a basic overview from what I've gathered, but if you are more curious check the Wikipedia page:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertzsprung-Russell_diagram

And Don't forget the link in the description to see the updated graph yourself!
Like my comment (and especially the video!) if you found this interesting! Another great video @minutephysics :D I'm always learning something new from you guys <3
snippet.textOriginal:
At 1:31 they flash the text "*Hertzsprung-Russell, anyone?".

If anyone is curious, Hertzsprung-Russell diagrams, or HRDs, originated from scatter plots comparing a star's luminosity to its temperature.  These scatter plots all have a main sequence, which I suppose in context would be the countries that have not dropped from the logarithmic curve or countries that do not appear to have the disease under control yet.  The video does not mention HRDs by name, I'm assuming because we're not talking about stars, but its the exact same concept.

These HRDs also do not plot against time to make it easier to see an overall effect (same as discussed in the video).  This feature, in many cases such as with Covid-19, makes it MUCH easier to analyze data and predict future outcomes.  If you want to simulate a time dimension, imagine the lines drawing themselves as countries' plotted curves are added to day by day (he explains how this is shown through animation).

That's a basic overview from what I've gathered, but if you are more curious check the Wikipedia page:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertzsprung-Russell_diagram

And Don't forget the link in the description to see the updated graph yourself!

snippet.textDisplay:
What really matters is NOT how many people caught the virus. It is how many people are dying from the virus. That does not mean 85 year olds or people with emphysema that caught the virus, etc. It also does not mean comparing a country like the US with 330 million people to one like Denmark with 6 million. Per capita numbers show how a country's program is really working.


As an example, Sweden is not bothering to test anymore. Thus, their numbers are going to freefall on the graph. They are assuming that everyone will catch it and are concentrating on treatment.
snippet.textOriginal:
What really matters is NOT how many people caught the virus.  It is how many people are dying from the virus.  That does not mean 85 year olds or people with emphysema that caught the virus, etc.  It also does not mean comparing a country like the US with 330 million people to one like Denmark with 6 million. Per capita numbers show how a country's program is really working.


As an example, Sweden is not bothering to test anymore. Thus, their numbers are going to freefall on the graph.  They are assuming that everyone will catch it and are concentrating on treatment.

snippet.textDisplay: There is a logical flaw in this. Any statistically valid prediction about the severance of of infection/contagion, in reference to the cycle of an epidemic, needs an estimate of convalescence. Given that specific time span, you need to only subtract the relative number of cured/recovered cases from the total of confirmed ones and you get the only curve you need.
snippet.textOriginal: There is a logical flaw in this. Any statistically valid prediction about the severance of of infection/contagion, in reference to the cycle of an epidemic, needs an estimate of convalescence. Given that specific time span, you need to only subtract the relative number of cured/recovered cases from the total of confirmed ones and you get the only curve you need.

snippet.textDisplay:
随着新冠病毒在其他国家广泛的传播，越来越多的国家开始将矛头指向了美国，关于美国才是新冠病毒来源的证据很多，对此中国在国内疫情出现的时候就对此发出了质疑。

结合当初军运会军人出现异常被特殊转移，如今又销声匿迹的情况中方希望美国能对这几位军人进行检测，但是美国方面并没有配合的意思。实际上美国也不可能允许其他国家和世界组织这样做，甚至在此前因为流感而死亡的人他们也拒绝进行检测。

除了中国之外，日本俄罗斯意大利伊朗也达成了一致，向美国“流感”讨要一个说法，特朗普欠世界一个解释。

病毒来源证据指向美国

据病毒学家的研究显示，美国是世界上唯一一个五种冠状病毒都有的国家，中国只发现了冠状家族的C型病毒，美国则是ABCDE一应俱全，“五毒”的称号实至名归。

对于美国的质疑首先是军运会上出现发热、腹泻的五名美军士兵被秘密转移，这五名军人当时是被专机带回美国的，如果美国事先不知道是新冠病毒感染，普通的发热腹泻会被当做感冒来处理，不可能会得到特殊待遇用专机送回，但是如今中国希望美国对这些士兵进行检测时美国却闭口不谈，之前的五名美军士兵销声匿迹查无此人。

再有美疾控中心主任亲自承认，在美国此前爆发的流感中有部分死亡患者实际上是感染了新冠病毒而非普通流感。除此之外意大利方面的研究也有新发现，可以确定的是早在中国疫情爆发之前，意大利就出现了新冠患者，只不过当时意大利并没有发现这是病毒在传播的情况。

美疫情大爆发也许早已埋下隐患

按照美方一些部门预测，未来可能感染新冠病毒的美国人将超过1.5亿，要知道美国总人口也才3亿，会做出这样悲观的预期，可见美国人们对病毒的起源也心知肚明吧。

之前没发现只是大量的美国人没有进行检测，一旦检测普及开，更多潜伏的或轻微感染的患者都会暴露出来。需要注意的是，美国目前每天进行检测的人并不多，但是“中招”的比例却相当的高，这说明新冠病毒在美国人之间早已传播开来。

也许他们中的大部分年轻人不会因此付出生命的代价，但是新冠肺炎对于中老年人来说却无异于灾难，此次疫情下一些地区甚至一整代的人都会消失，这对于这个世界来说都是莫大的悲哀。

美疫情大爆发也许早已埋下隐患

按照美方一些部门预测，未来可能感染新冠病毒的美国人将超过1.5亿，要知道美国总人口也才3亿，会做出这样悲观的预期，可见美国人们对病毒的起源也心知肚明吧。

之前没发现只是大量的美国人没有进行检测，一旦检测普及开，更多潜伏的或轻微感染的患者都会暴露出来。需要注意的是，美国目前每天进行检测的人并不多，但是“中招”的比例却相当的高，这说明新冠病毒在美国人之间早已传播开来。

也许他们中的大部分年轻人不会因此付出生命的代价，但是新冠肺炎对于中老年人来说却无异于灾难，此次疫情下一些地区甚至一整代的人都会消失，这对于这个世界来说都是莫大的悲哀。

snippet.textDisplay:
There's a couple of things you missed that are actually very important.
While you pointed out that number of cases is not number of infected people, you overlooked that the cases counted are not necessarily comparable, either. A country that tests very aggressively will have a lot of confirmed cases, but a lot of these cases will be mild ones - mildly symptomatic or even asymptomatic. Detecting those is actually good, because it allows to isolate these people and prevent them from infecting others - so despite the fact that case numbers will look high, control over the spread is much better. On the other hand, a country which is already on the verge of breakdown or in full chaos will likely only test what's ending up at the hospital anyway. So the former may even count more cases than the latter, but the percentage of infections being tracked is higher and the bulk of the cases being found is much milder.

Another point: we're on the verge of getting new tests that will simplify testing - consequently, the number of confirmed cases is likely to explode. Case numbers post quick-test will not be comparable with case numbers pre-quick test.


Similarly, a country in which the situation relaxes may find the resources to do more out of hospital testing and see case numbers rise again more quickly.


So simply comparing number of cases largely tracks an artifact of test availability that says precious little as to how bad the situation is. I think the number of deaths is a more solid parameter, though even that has problems, since not every country is doing postmortem diagnosis and thus, people dying of previously undiagnosed COVID-19 don't necessarily get counted.
snippet.textOriginal:
There's a couple of things you missed that are actually very important.
While you pointed out that number of cases is not number of infected people, you overlooked that the cases counted are not necessarily comparable, either. A country that tests very aggressively will have a lot of confirmed cases, but a lot of these cases will be mild ones - mildly symptomatic or even asymptomatic. Detecting those is actually good, because it allows to isolate these people and prevent them from infecting others - so despite the fact that case numbers will look high, control over the spread is much better. On  the other hand, a country which is already on the verge of breakdown or in full chaos will likely only test what's ending up at the hospital anyway. So the former may even count more cases than the latter, but the percentage of infections being tracked is higher and the bulk of the cases being found is much milder. 

Another point:  we're on the verge of getting new tests that will simplify testing - consequently, the number of confirmed cases is likely to explode. Case numbers post quick-test will not be comparable with case numbers pre-quick test.


 Similarly, a country in which the situation relaxes may find the resources to do more out of hospital testing and see case numbers rise again more quickly.


So simply comparing number of cases largely tracks an artifact of test availability that says precious little as to how bad the situation is. I think the number of deaths is a more solid parameter, though even that has problems, since not every country is doing postmortem diagnosis and thus, people dying of previously undiagnosed COVID-19 don't necessarily get counted.
